item.title: Russia’s Invasion Shadows U.N. Assembly Amid ‘Colossal Global Dysfunction’
item.description: Presidents Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey and Emmanuel Macron of France used the gathering as a stage to cast themselves as would-be peacemakers in the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: António Guterres, the United Nations secretary general, said in his opening remarks that the world is in peril: “We cannot go on like this.”

item.title: Trump’s Lawyers Skirt Question of Declassification in Documents Case
item.description: The former president insists he shouldn’t have to state in a legal proceeding that he declassified the documents, while casting doubt on their status.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: No credible evidence has emerged to support former President Donald J. Trump’s claim that he had a standing order to declassify everything he took from the Oval Office.

item.title: Justice Dept. Charges 48 in Brazen Pandemic Aid Fraud in Minnesota
item.description: The defendants were charged with stealing $240 million intended to feed children, in what appears to be the largest theft so far from a pandemic-era program.
item.dc:creator: David A. Fahrenthold
item.media:description: The indictments said the defendants had pulled in millions of dollars a week by taking money from federal anti-hunger programs for meals they never served.

item.title: Health Panel Recommends Anxiety Screening for All Adults Under 65
item.description: The guidance comes as Americans are coping with illness, isolation and loss from the pandemic, as well as other stressors like inflation and rising crime.
item.dc:creator: Emily Baumgaertner
item.category: United States Preventive Services Task Force
item.media:description: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommendation is intended to help identify warning signs during routine examinations.

item.title: Will Cheri Beasley’s North Carolina Senate Race Break Democratic Hearts Again?
item.description: Since a blue wave in the state in 2008, winning elections hasn’t been easy for Democrats. But polling is evenly divided as Cheri Beasley and Ted Budd compete.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Logan R. Cyrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cheri Beasley arriving for a campaign event at Johnson C. Smith University in Charlotte, N.C., on Friday. She is running for Senate as a judge above the fray.

item.title: Donors Worry About a Cash Crunch for Voter Registration Groups
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:description: In 2020, foundations and private donors poured millions into democracy-related projects, including voter registration. But now some of that money may be drying up.

item.title: N.Y.C. Subway System to Install Security Cameras in Train Cars
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul said the installations, which grew from a pilot project after a mass shooting in Brooklyn, would allay riders’ anxieties.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ley
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stations in the subway system are outfitted with cameras, but cars have been a blind spot.

item.title: Apps Like Flashfood and Too Good to Go Let You Buy Food That Was Going to be Thrown Away
item.description: Several companies say they are tackling food waste by connecting people with unsold food from restaurants and grocery stores.
item.dc:creator: Clare Toeniskoetter
item.media:credit: Lawrence Agyei for The New York Times

item.title: In ‘Reboot,’ Everything Old Is New, to Streaming
item.description: This new Hulu comedy pokes fun at TV’s obsession with bringing back past shows.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Devin Oktar Yalkin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Levitan first had the idea for “Reboot” during the controversy in which Roseanne Barr was fired from her own revived sitcom.

item.title: Is America Really in a Mental Health Crisis?
item.description: Many in power would prefer to kick questions like “What caused the mental health crisis?” and “Who benefits?” out of sight. Don’t let them.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Carr

item.title: The Border Crisis Could Still Be Biden’s Opportunity
item.description: But first it would help to admit that the border is not secure.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens

item.title: Three Paths Toward an Endgame for Putin’s War
item.description: But here are three possibilities.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man painting over the Russian flag in a recently recaptured Ukrainian village.

item.title: Yvon Chouinard Is the Founder of Patagonia. He’s Also My ‘Dirtbag’ Friend.
item.description: Yvon Chouinard has given away his company in his fight to save the planet.
item.dc:creator: Tom Brokaw
item.media:credit: Laure Joliet for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yvon Chouinard in the original Tin Shed, the blacksmith shop where he forged pitons for climbing.

item.title: Sweden’s Far Right Is Rising
item.description: The idea of Sweden as a land of equal opportunity, safe from the plagues of extreme left or extreme right that haunt other countries, is gone.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Asbrink
item.media:description: Supporters of the Sweden Democrats political party during its election night rally.

item.title: Is There Too Much ‘Mental Health’ Awareness in the United States?
item.description: Has the term become so expansive as to be meaningless?
item.dc:creator: Huw Green
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie. Photographs from Getty Images

item.title: Glenn Youngkin Is Playing a Dangerous Game
item.description: The governor believes he needs to cater to and actually support election questioners and deniers to have a shot at leading the Republican Party.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Glenn Youngkin of Virginia, speaking in Michigan at a “Red Wave Party.”

item.title: ‘Serial:’ Season 1
item.description: A high school senior named Hae Min Lee disappeared one day after school in 1999, in Baltimore County, Md. A month later, her body was found in a city park. She’d been strangled. Her 17-year-old ex-boyfriend, Adnan Syed, was charged with murder, and within a year, he was sentenced to life in prison. The case against him was largely based on the story of one witness, Adnan’s friend Jay, who testified that he had helped Adnan bury Hae’s body. But Adnan has always maintained that he had nothing to do with Hae’s death. Some people believe he has been telling the truth. Many others don’t.

item.title: Who gets to use gas?
item.description: Some African countries, which have done little to cause the climate crisis, say they should. Many climate activists on the continent call the idea “folly.” We unpack the debate.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: Gas flares in Idu, a town in the Niger Delta of Nigeria.

item.title: Andrew Sean Greer on Writing ‘Less’
item.description: The novelist discusses his Pulitzer-winning comedy about the travels and travails of a heartbroken writer, and William Finnegan talks about surfing.

item.title: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Can We Trust the Polls?
item.description: Polling error is not inevitable, and there are signs that 2022 may be different.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pollsters are setting sail yet again this year. Is it a little scary? Yes.

item.title: Migrants Who Were Flown to Martha’s Vineyard Sue Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis
item.description: The Venezuelans who unexpectedly found themselves on a Massachusetts island say in their suit that Florida officials made “made false promises and false representations” to them.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina and Remy Tumin
item.media:description: The lawsuit against the Florida governor and other state officials came less than a week after roughly 50 Venezuelan migrants were taken from Texas to Martha’s Vineyard in Massachusetts.

item.title: E. Jean Carroll, Who Says Trump Raped Her, Plans to Use New Law to Prove It
item.description: E. Jean Carroll, a former advice columnist for Elle, had already sued the former president for defamation after he branded her a liar
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser
item.media:description: The writer, E. Jean Carroll, has accused former President Donald J. Trump of raping her in the 1990s.

item.title: On a Grim Anniversary, 230 Pilot Whales Are Stranded in Tasmania
item.description: “At least 95 percent will die, because the ocean’s just so fierce,” said a boat skipper on the scene, where 470 whales were also beached in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Department of Natural Resources and Environment Tasmania, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Pilot whales stranded on the western coast of Tasmania on Wednesday.

item.title: Bill, Hillary and Chelsea Clinton Return to Center Stage. Their Own.
item.description: After going dark during Hillary Clinton’s 2016 presidential campaign, the Clinton Global Initiative is back.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kulish
item.media:description: Former President Bill Clinton welcomed the crowd at the Clinton Global Initiative conference on Monday, which has been on hiatus for six years.

item.title: Do Antidepressants Work for Severe PMS?
item.description: Premenstrual dysphoric disorder, or PMDD, is an extreme and often debilitating form of PMS that can be tricky to manage. Here’s what treatments work.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: IUD Insertion: What to Know and Expect
item.description: Intrauterine devices are highly effective, but some women find insertion painful. Here’s how to prepare.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: How Black Women Can Interpret Those Scary Health Statistics
item.description: Doomsday headlines are nothing new. But over time they can damage your mental health if you’re not careful.
item.dc:creator: Jacquelynn Kerubo

item.title: Are Plan B and Body Weight Interconnected?
item.description: Researchers have looked into why and how weight influences emergency contraception but have come up against several unknowns. Here’s what we know.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Dani Blum

item.title: How to Recognize and Treat Perimenopause Symptoms
item.description: We break down the signs, causes and treatment options for five common symptoms.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Monica Garwood

item.title: In Istanbul’s Private Retreats of the Sultans, Time Stands Still
item.description: The elegant pavilions and summer palaces known as kasir offer a glimpse of history and an intimate and enticing slice of Ottoman life.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Morrow
item.media:credit: Bradley Secker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hidiv Kasri, in Beykoz on the Asian side of Istanbul, was built by the Egyptians looking to court Turkish power to their side.

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
